Situation1: Many prospects ask detailed technical questions about the new service that the script only partially addresses.
Expectation2: Contribute to community well-being through paying taxes, following public health and safety guidance, and helping in emergencies
Situation2: Tax documents are organized a month before the deadline, and a free vaccine clinic runs this weekend at the community center.
Story:
I sit at my desk, headset snug, fingers poised over the keyboard. As a telemarketer, I’m expected to handle customer objections smoothly, but today, the calls are relentless. Prospects keep asking technical questions about our new service—questions my script only half-answers. I feel the pressure to sound confident, to keep them interested, but I’m fumbling, improvising, hoping I don’t mislead anyone. My supervisor’s eyes flick to me, expecting results.

But my mind drifts. As a citizen, I know I should be at the community center this weekend. There’s a free vaccine clinic, and I want to help out, maybe even volunteer. My tax documents are already sorted, so I have the time. I feel a responsibility to contribute, to be present for my neighbors, especially after the tough year we’ve all had.

The demands pull at me—my job needs my focus, my community needs my presence. I feel the tension in my chest, torn between the script in front of me and the sense of duty tugging from outside these office walls.
